1956

march 5, 1912.

Dr, K. 1. Kwan,

Iraperial medical College,

Tientsin, China.

My dear Dr. Kwan:

When your boy left us last year to return to China, I went

over with him in detail his financial statement, and asked him to explain the

situation fully to you on his return to China.

On the 24th of November, 1911, I forwarded a sta tenant to that 
date, showing a deficit of $981.36. Since that time I have paid 0-9 add -
trional bill, that of Dr. Albert s. Hulme of this town, for dentist, to the

amount of $4.00.

The total overdraft to da te, therefore, is $985.36.

I have desired to do nothing that would convey the impression

that I was unduly anxious about this account, and hence have not written

about it before.

I realize also that the unsettled conditions in China to day

must have their effect on the financial situation in general and on the means

of individuals; consequently I have been more than ever reluctant to urge

an early settlement.

I can continue to carry the account for a time longer,

and will gladly do so in case you desire to hero one.

On the other hand, it

would be a convenience to have the matter settled at a comparatively early

date if it is reasonable to make this request.

Several of our other Chinese

boys, notably the Sun brothers, have generally kept fairly generous balances

on hand, and kr. Tong Kaison, who has been ay chief adviser in regard to these

boys, had authorized de to draw from individual surplus funds in the cases of

boys who might be temporarily behind in their own funds. In this way it 
has not been necessary for ne generally to borrow outside, and hence be 
compelled to meet interest charges. On one or two occasions, however, I

have had to do this.

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Letter about the status of his son's account and following up on the statement sent on November 14, 1911. Stearns apologizes for writing about the deficit of $985.36 in the account; states he was reluctant to bring this up given the financial situation in China and for individuals. He notes that he would like to have the account settled, and that, since the Sun brothers and others have maintained generous  balances, he has not had to draw on funds external to the Chinese students' overall balance, except for in a few instances. Further, should the Sun brothers leave Andover, it will be necessary to take steps to charge interest on funds applied from other sources. He expresses his regret about the situation and closes with saying that he misses Sung Sing and wishes that China will reach its potential and high ideals.
